Research:

I am an experimental particle physicist. I study elementary particles and their interactions through analyzing data collected from the Large Hadron Collider. I also participate in the R & D for developing next generator collider detectors for future experimental programs.

Search and discovery of the Higgs boson at CERN's Large Hadron Collider

The search for the Higgs boson was a 40-year endeavor of generations of particle physicists, and it was one of the most important goals of the LHC physics program. I was one of the leading contributors to the observation of the Higgs boson decaying to two photons using the ATLAS detector. I also made significant contribution to the determination of the spin of the then-newly discovered Higgs boson.

Meausring the Properties of the Higgs boson

The production of Higgs boson in association with top quarks (ttH) is one of the main production modes of the Higgs boson that are not yet observed. The observation of this process will be the next milestone in the study of the Higgs boson as it will be the first direct evidence of the top Higgs Yukawa coupling. Measuring the ttH production not only will provide a model-independent determination of the top Yukawa coupling, but also will be sensitive to potential effects of BSM physics.

I have been developing novel analysis technique to significantly improve ATLAS experiment's sensitivity to this process. Specifically, I designed a Multivariate Analysis using Boosted Decision Tree to separate ttH signal events from large multijet background events in the diphoton channel. This work has been published in Ref.[]. I am currently working to further refine this method and apply it to ttH events in the leptonic events. This work is expected to help us observe the ttH production by the end of the LHC Run-2.

In a longer term, I plan to develop analysis strategies to probe potential new physics that may affect the properties of the ttH production.

Search for Physics beyond the Standard Model

The Large Hadron Collider is a discovery machine, and I am always excited by the opportunity of discovering something that may fundamentally change our understanding of the Laws of Nature. Lately, I have focused my search effort on the multijet final state, which has long been considered as one of the most challenging places to look for new physics. At the beginning of the LHC Run-2,

I led a search for TeV-scale black hole production at the Large Hadron Collider. This search was a probe of BSM physics at the highest energy accessible at a collider.

  • Search for black hole with mass up to 9 TeV decaying to large number of SM particles via Hawking radiation
  • Fit-based data driven estimation strategy

Recently, I have been working on a search for massive supersymmetric particles decaying to many jets via R-parity violating couplings. This search is also conducted in the multijet final state, however, it deals with physics at a much lower energy scale compared to the black hole search and requires new strategy to suppress and estimate background:

  • Search for particles with masses up to 2 TeV
  • Exploit large-radius jets and their substructure information
  • Implement novel data driven background estimation method
  • Develop fully data driven systematic uncertainty estimation

Earlier, I have produced a paper on the search for Universal Extral Dimensions using events with two photons and large missing transverse energy. This search was one of the very first new physics searches published from the LHC experiments.

Detector R&D for future colliders

A High Luminosity LHC (HL-LHC) run is planned to take place in 2026. This program is expected to collect approximately 3000 fb-1 data after ten years running. This data set allows us to measure the properties of the Higgs boson at an unprecedented precision and to explore a much larger phase space for BSM physics.

I have worked on the R&D for the upgrade of the ATLAS Inner Tracker (ITk) for the upcoming HL-LHC run. This includes studying properties of the mechanical support structure, testing electrical components of the protyping detectors, exploring new hardware based track seeded trigger, as well as simulation study of the tracking performance.

I look forward to continuing my contribution to the Phase-2 upgrade efforts that enable the LHC experiments to fully exploit the physics opportunities brought about by the HL-LHC program. In a longer term, I am also interested in conducting R&D for detector technologies needed for future hadron and/or lepton colliders.

Search, Explore, and Observe Natural Wonders on Earth

Otherwise in life, I enjoy outdoor life, exploring natural wonders by hiking, driving, and camping!
